message.content: This question requires some knowledge about the properties of different surfaces and how they affect the sled's runners. When a sled runs off the snow and onto the asphalt, the friction between the sled runners and the asphalt causes them to heat up. Option (A) is incorrect because the runners do not fly off. Option (B) is incorrect because the runners do not turn sideways. Option (D) is incorrect because the runners are not cooling down when they transition from snow to asphalt.

This question requires some basic knowledge about the properties of different surfaces and their effects on objects. When a sled runs off the snow and onto the asphalt, the friction between the sled's runners and the asphalt causes them to heat up. This is because the asphalt surface creates more friction than the snow, which generates heat. Option (A) is incorrect because the runners of the sled do not fly off. Option (B) is unlikely because turning sideways would not be a direct effect of moving from snow to asphalt. Option (D) is incorrect because the runners would not cool down when moving from snow to asphalt.

This question requires an understanding of the friction between sled runners and different surfaces. When a sled runs off the snow and onto the asphalt, the friction between the runners and the asphalt causes them to heat up. Option (A) is incorrect because there is no indication that the runners would fly off. Option (B) is unlikely because the runners are designed to move straight and turning sideways would impede their movement. Option (D) is also incorrect because the runners are not cooling down, but rather heating up due to the increased friction.

This question asks about the effect of transitioning from snow to asphalt on a sled's runners. When a sled runs off the snow and onto the asphalt, the friction between the runners and the road surface causes the runners to heat up. Option (A) is incorrect because the runners would not fly off unless there was an external force acting on them. Option (B) is incorrect because the runners would continue to face forward, parallel to the direction of motion. Option (D) is incorrect because the transition from snow to asphalt would not cause the runners to cool down, but rather heat up due to increased friction.

Option (A) is incorrect because the runners of the sled do not fly off when transitioning from snow to asphalt. Option (B) is incorrect because the runners of the sled do not turn sideways in this situation. Option (D) is incorrect because the runners of the sled are not cooling down when transitioning from snow to asphalt.

This question requires some basic knowledge about the physics of friction and the different properties of snow and asphalt. When a sled transitions from the snow to the asphalt, the friction between the runners and the asphalt will cause them to heat up. This is because asphalt has a higher coefficient of friction compared to snow, which means there is greater resistance and heat generated when the sled slides on the asphalt. Option (A) is incorrect because the runners of the sled do not fly off. Option (B) is also incorrect because the runners do not turn sideways. Option (D) is incorrect because the runners do not cool down when transitioning to asphalt.
